contentrichtext.text: {{Use British English|date=February 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox Prime Minister |honorific-prefix = [[The Honourable]] |name=Young Vivian |image= |order = [[Premier of Niue]] |term_start = 1 May 2002 |term_end = 19 June 2008 |deputy = Hon. Fisa Igilisi Pihigia MP |predecessor = [[Sani Lakatani]] |successor = [[Toke Talagi]] |order2 = [[Premier of Niue]] |term_start2 = 12 December 1992 |term_end2 = 9 March 1993 |deputy2 = |predecessor2 =Sir [[Robert Rex]] |successor2 = [[Frank Lui]] |constituency = [[Hakupu]] |birth_date = {{b-da|12 November 1935}} |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |spouse = Vaitofuola (nee Ikiua-Lupo) |party = [[Niue People's Action Party]], then independent }} '''Mititaiagimene Young Vivian''' (born 12 November 1935) is a [[Niue]]an politician who has twice been the [[Premier of Niue|premier]] of his country. Representing the [[Niue People's Action Party]], he defeated sitting premier [[Sani Lakatani]] in May 2002 elections. Vivian had previously served as premier for a brief period from 12 December 1992 to 9 March 1993 following the death of Sir [[Robert Rex]]. He had also previously been the secretary general of the [[Pacific Community]] from 1979 until 1982. He was re-elected to the [[Niue Assembly]] (national Parliament) unopposed in [[Niuean general election, 2005|elections that were held in April 2005]]. He was again re-elected unopposed to Parliament in the [[Niuean general election, 2008|2008 elections]].<ref>[http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=39950 "Niue Premier and Cabinet returned un-opposed as nominations close"], Radio New Zealand International, 23 May 2008</ref> However, he lost his position as premier when he was successfully challenged by fellow MP [[Toke Talagi]] after that election. Talagi was elected premier by the Assembly, with fourteen votes to Vivian's five, and one abstaining.<ref>[http://www.radioaustralia.net.au/news/stories/200806/s2279886.htm?tab=latest "Talagi declared new Niue premier"], ABC Radio Australia, 19 June 2008</ref> He has also been Niue's Minister of Health and Minister of Tourism. In his political career, which has spanned over 30 years, Young Vivian has held most (if not all) ministerial portfolios in Niue's government – mostly during his many years as a Cabinet Minister in the governments of Sir Robert Rex (in office 1974–1992) and of [[Frank Lui]] (in office 1993–1999). ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{s-start}} {{s-gov}} {{S-bef|before=[[Robert Rex]]}} {{S-ttl|rows=2 |title=[[Premier of Niue]]|years=1992–1993<br>2002–2008}} {{S-aft|after=[[Frank Lui]]}} {{S-bef|before=[[Sani Lakatani]]}} {{S-aft|after=[[Toke Talagi]]}} {{end}} {{NiuePMs}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME =Vivian, Young | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = New Zealand politician | DATE OF BIRTH =12 November 1935 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vivian, Young}} [[Category:1935 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Premiers of Niue]] [[Category:Members of the Niue Assembly]] [[Category:Secretariat of the Pacific Community]] [[Category:Niue People's Party politicians]] [[Category:Government ministers of Niue]]
